channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: More Agents Head to Minnesota as U.S. Takes Over Shooting Investigation
item.description: A day after an ICE agent fatally shot a 37-year-old woman in Minneapolis, the governor activated the state’s National Guard, and 100 more federal agents were also being deployed.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Mitch Smith and Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents attempted to disperse demonstrators outside of a federal building near Minneapolis on Thursday morning.

item.title: U.S. Border Patrol Agents Shoot 2 in Portland During Traffic Stop
item.description: The shooting came as Minneapolis grappled with a federal agent’s killing of a woman a day earlier, prompting calls from local leaders for an end to the Trump administration’s immigration crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin, Hamed Aleaziz and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers blocked off an area near where victims of a shooting involving federal agents were found in Portland, Ore., on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Addresses Venezuela, Greenland and Presidential Power in New York Times Interview
item.description: On topic after topic, President Trump made clear that he would be the arbiter of any limits to his authorities, not international law or treaties.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager, Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: The Next Phase of Trump’s Renovations: A New ‘Upper West Wing’
item.description: Besides changes to the White House, President Trump also said he planned to tear up the brick walkways in Lafayette Park and replace them with granite.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers, Luke Broadwater, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: In President Trump’s vision, a second level with office space would be built on top of the colonnade that connects the West Wing to the White House residence.

item.title: The Many Faces of Trump: What We Saw When We Interviewed the President
item.description: He let reporters in on a call with Colombia’s president. He complained about Zohran Mamdani. He called JD Vance and Marco Rubio “kids.” Inside an unpredictable evening with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Doug Mills
item.media:description: President Trump spent nearly two hours being interviewed by New York Times reporters on Wednesday.

item.title: Senate Advances Measure to Curb Trump’s Use of Force in Venezuela
item.description: A handful of Republicans joined Democrats to allow the measure to move forward, reflecting concerns in both parties about the administration’s strategy.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: “Make no mistake: Bombing another nation’s capital and removing their president is an act of war, plain and simple,” Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, said before the vote.

item.title: These 5 Republicans Broke With Trump on Venezuela War Powers
item.description: The Republican defectors paved the way for a debate that could expose bipartisan concern about President Trump’s actions in Venezuela. Mr. Trump called for them to lose their seats.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Susan Collins is the only one of the five Republican defectors who is facing re-election this year.

item.title: Iran Is Cut Off From Internet as Protests Calling for Regime Change Intensify
item.description: As protests swelled around the country, Iran’s internet was shut down, and the heads of its judiciary and its security services warned of a harsh response amid calls for “freedom, freedom.”
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Pranav Baskar and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman checking her phone in Tehran in October.

item.title: House Passes Doomed Bill to Restore ACA Subsidies
item.description: The passage of the bill was a triumph for Democrats, who drew substantial Republican backing. But it has no path forward, and an election-year compromise is a long shot.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Morgan Lieberman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Millions of Americans have relied on subsidies, which were expanded during the coronavirus pandemic, to help them afford coverage on federal health care exchanges.

item.title: Congress Tries, but Fails, to Take a Stand for Its Own Powers
item.description: House votes to override a pair of Trump vetoes were an unusual bid by some in the G.O.P. to assert their own branch’s prerogatives. But they fell short.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The move was described by one of President Trump’s allies as designed to “slap the president in the face.”

item.title: Trump Urges Voters to Oust Republicans, Including Susan Collins
item.description: After five G.O.P. senators joined Democrats on a war powers vote, the president lashed out, including at his party’s most politically endangered senator.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Susan M. Collins, Republican of Maine, was one of five Republicans who voted with Democrats to start a debate over restricting the president’s ability to use military force in Venezuela. Of the five, Ms. Collins is the only one up for re-election this year.

item.title: Dogs Build Their Vocabularies Like Toddlers
item.description: Eavesdropping on their owners seems to help some toy-crazy and talented pups learn more words.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Russia Appears to Use Nuclear-Capable Missile in Ukraine
item.description: If confirmed, the use of the missile would be an ominous threat to Ukraine and its Western allies.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier firing a howitzer toward the front lines of Pokrovsk, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Ukraine Awards Major Lithium Project to Investors With Links to Trump
item.description: Ronald S. Lauder, a billionaire friend of Mr. Trump, is among the investors. The move comes as the Trump administration looks for investment opportunities in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ronald S. Lauder is one of the investors who won the bid to mine lithium deposits in Ukraine. He has known President Trump since college.

item.title: Inside Myanmar’s Gilded Capital, Empty Streets and Moldy Corners
item.description: Myanmar’s junta created a capital to withstand an invasion. Now, the military struggles to project an image of control over a crumbling nation.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: An empty road in front of decommissioned tanks at the Defense Services Museum complex in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, the day after a vote in December.

item.title: Hochul and Mamdani Announce Plan to Make N.Y. Child Care Universal
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul and Mayor Zohran Mamdani described a complex and expensive expansion of child care in New York City that would add programs for 2-year-olds.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes, Eliza Shapiro and Grace Ashford
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: The announcement came days into the term of Mayor Zohran Mamdani, center, a democratic socialist who ran on a promise to make child care free for all New York City children under 5.

item.title: Amid Opening Sprint, Mamdani Paused to Socialize With Steven Spielberg
item.description: Zohran Mamdani, the new mayor of New York, made a private visit to the billionaire film director’s Central Park West apartment this week.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman and Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Monica Schipper/Getty Images; José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times

item.title: The Rise of the Self-Serve Blood Test
item.description: The start-up Function will send practically anyone to a lab for extensive medical testing, no physical required. Is that a good thing?
item.dc:creator: Kristen V. Brown
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kimberly Crisp, a former pharmacist, was intrigued by the prospect of using Function Health to figure out a natural way to get her blood sugar levels down.

item.title: Once Again, a Newfoundland Town Rescues Stranded Passengers
item.description: After 9/11, Gander took in thousands of people whose flights were diverted. History repeated on a smaller scale this week.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: The airport in Gander, Newfoundland, where three flights were diverted this week for bad weather, stranding travelers.

item.title: Former Uvalde Teacher’s Testimony Throws a Trial Into Chaos
item.description: Lawyers for a former officer charged with abandoning children in the police response accused prosecutors of withholding information. A judge ruled prosecutors had erred but denied a motion for a mistrial.
item.dc:creator: Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Eric Gay
item.media:description: Adrian Gonzales, the former school police officer in Uvalde, Texas, at the Nueces County Courthouse in Corpus Christi on Tuesday.

item.title: What Happens When No One Can Say No to Trump?
item.description: After the capture of the Venezuelan president, Nicolás Maduro, over the weekend, “Trump is setting a new course for the country where he can use the military to do just about anything he wants,” argues Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury. “No one is allowed to say ‘no’ to Trump.”

item.title: I’m the Mayor of Minneapolis. Trump Is Lying to You.
item.description: This administration is making cities less safe.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Frey
item.media:credit: Charly Triballeau/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: N.Y.P.D. Fatally Shoots Blade-Wielding Man in Hospital, Officials Say
item.description: The man had cut and then barricaded himself in a blood-spattered room with a patient and a security guard at NewYork-Presbyterian Brooklyn Methodist Hospital, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan and Tim Balk
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police responded to 911 calls about a man with a knife inside Methodist Hospital in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

item.title: NASA Will Bring I.S.S. Astronauts Home Early After Medical Issue
item.description: After canceling a spacewalk planned for Thursday, the space agency’s administrator said it was erring on the side of caution and bringing a crew of four home in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang and Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Steve Nesius/Reuters

item.title: Families of Slain Idaho Students Sue the University the Killer Attended
item.description: A new lawsuit claims that Washington State University, where Bryan Kohberger was a Ph.D. student, failed to take decisive action on earlier complaints that he was stalking women.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra
item.media:credit: Rajah Bose for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial at the University of Idaho campus in 2022.

item.title: Why Cambodia Handed Over a Man Accused of Stealing Billions in Crypto Scam
item.description: Experts say the scam industry has become a pillar of Cambodia’s economy, but it is under pressure from other countries to crack down.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A building in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, listed on the website of Prince Holding Group as its headquarters, on Thursday. The company has been accused by U.S. prosecutors of operating cyberscams.
